Project Description  The Amu Zang irrigation system is located in Surkandarya Province, 
and comprises a cascade of pumping stations and the network of 
irrigation canals conveying water from the Amu Darya  River to a 
command area of 96,800  hectares (ha). The Project will provide 
support for (i) cost-effective and prioritized rehabilitation of the Amu 
Zang  irrigation  system,  (ii)  improved  water  management  and 
enhanced capacities for water management agencies, (iii) improved 
agricultural  support  services  for  newly-emerging  private  farms 
through  development  of  rural  institutions  such  as  water  users 
associations (WUAs) and agriculture service centers (ASCs), and 
(iv)  farm  demonstration  and  training  programs  to  introduce  new 
technologies  for  water  saving,  soil  improvement,  and  crop 
diversification. The Project will facilitate the policy and institutional 
reforms by helping the Government in (i) developing a sustainable 
cost recovery policy, (ii) enhancing the procedures for developing 
WUAs at the national level, (iii) improving the procurement quota 
systems for cotton and grain, and (iv) introducing water delivery fees 
in the project area. 
   
Rationale  Some 400,000 people live in the five districts covered by the Amu 
Zang irrigation system. The people within the project area depend 
primarily on irrigated agriculture for their livelihood, since the industry 
and service sectors are less developed than they are in other parts 
of Uzbekistan. Poverty incidence in Amu Zang area is estimated to 
be 31.4% compared with the national average of 27.5%.  
 
The Amu Zang irrigation system was built in 1973 and is now at the 
end of its useful life. The reliability and capacity of the aging pumping 
cascade has significantly declined and high sediment levels in the 
pumped water damaged the pumping equipment. A large amount of 
sediments  in  canals  and  drains  is  reducing  their  capacities  and 
increasing  the  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs.  Due  to 
canals’ deteriorated condition and a high level of seepage, only 
about 50% of water reach farmers' fields. Unless a major overhaul is 
done,  some  of  the  key  components  of  the  main  system  could 
collapse in less than 5 years. Any collapse of the system would have 
devastating effects on a large number of the rural population, whose 
livelihood are directly dependent on the system. There are only very 
few employment alternatives in the area.

  The negative environmental impacts of the sudden decommissioning 
of  large-scale  irrigation  would  be  significant  and  are  likely  to 
exacerbate land degradation. 
   
The proposed Project offers valuable opportunities for the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to help the Government address important 
reform  issues  such  as  strengthening  irrigation  and  water 
management, formulating and implementing irrigation cost recovery

reform initiatives.  
   
Goal and Objective  The project goal is to maintain and improve agricultural productivity 
and farm income on a sustained basis. The project objectives are to 
(i) increase the reliability, efficiency, and sustainability of irrigation 
water supply of the Amu Zang irrigation system; and (ii) facilitate and 
accelerate agriculture sector reforms in the project area.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Amu Zang Irrigation Rehabilitation Project. The report also 
describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Support to Policy and Institutional Reforms in 
the Water Sector, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority 
delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. The project framework is in Appendix 1.  
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  With an average annual rainfall of 100–200 millimeters, crop farming in Uzbekistan is 
heavily dependent on irrigation. About 88% of the country’s 4.8 million hectares (ha) of arable 
area is irrigated. Irrigation water supplies come almost entirely from the Amu Darya and Syr 
Darya rivers. Irrigated agriculture accounts for 35% of the gross domestic product (GDP), 45% 
of employment, and 60%  of export revenues. Uzbekistan has a comparative advantage in 
growing cotton, making it currently the world’s fifth largest producer and the second largest 
exporter of cotton. Cotton is grown on about 42% of the total cultivated area, and accounts for 
close to 40% of Uzbekistan’s export earnings. Uzbekistan has used foreign exchange proceeds 
from cotton exports to support its import substitution policy and continues to depend on these 
earnings to sustain its industrial production. Wheat is also regarded as a strategic crop and is 
grown on 33% of the total cultivated area. As a landlocked country with limited physical access 
to international markets and with food security as a major concern, Uzbekistan has put wheat 
production at the center of the Government’s policy of food security.  
3.  Since independence in 1991, the overall performance of agriculture sector has been 
disappointing. Continued declines were observed in the production and productivity of the main 
cash crop—cotton. While the total national output of cotton was 4.6 million tons in 1991, it 
dropped to 3.17 million tons in 2002 because of declines in both area and per ha yield.  The 
decline in cotton production also coincided with the Government’s active promotion of policy of 
food security through state-controlled pricing and procurement systems. Between 1991 and 
2002, wheat production increased from 0.6 million tons to around 4.7 million tons. Much of the 
increases in wheat production was achieved by expanding the land area previously used for 
cotton and by increasing inputs on a per ha basis.  
4.  The overall poor performance of agriculture and the relatively low international prices of 
cotton in recent years have caused widespread farm losses, accumulated debts, and declining 
incomes for agricultural producers. As a result, the livelihood of the rural population has 
seriously deteriorated.  There is at present no official definition of poverty line in the country. A 
recent (2003) assessment conducted by the World Bank1 using 2,000 household survey data, 
estimated the food poverty line at SUM3,601 per capita per month and the national poverty 
incidence at 27.5%. Most of the poor reside in the rural areas. It was noted that seasonal 
unemployment in the rural areas reduced the income and consumption of the rural population 
by 50% on average. About 35% of the unemployed are from poor households.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
5.  Most of the country’s extensive  irrigation and drainage (I&D)  infrastructure that was 
developed in the 1960s and 1970s, has now reached the end of their useful life. Deterioration 
has accelerated since independence due to large transfers out of the agriculture sector and 
limited  allocation  of  funds  for  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  and  rehabilitation.  The 
Government’s capacity  to plan, design, and operate I&D systems is also inadequate as the 
design institutes, once responsible for developing water and I&D systems in Uzbekistan as well 
as in whole Central Asia, have lost most of their technical staff. Water users have virtually no 
participation  in  managing  I&D systems. As a result,  the O&M of the  I&D system is below 
acceptable standards. The consequences are excessive water losses, low irrigation efficiencies, 
waterlogging  and  widespread  soil  salinization,  and  declining  crop  yields.  The 
deterioration/losses of the resource base for agricultural production is estimated to cost the 
country about $1.0 billion annually in economic prices. 
6.  Rehabilitation of the I&D infrastructure is key to ensuring a secure supply of water and 
stimulating growth for the entire communities of hundreds of thousands people, who came into 
being solely because of irrigation development and settlement schemes. If not rehabilitated, the 
deteriorating schemes will either become  dysfunctional or lose  a significant part of irrigated 
farms, causing major negative socioeconomic impacts. The poor operational status of I&D 
infrastructure also exacerbates the already high water application rates and rapidly reduces the 
quality  of  farmland  through  rising  water  tables  and  salinization.  The  environmental 
consequences of land degradation are already substantial and are likely to matter considerably 
unless more is invested in the maintenance of I&D infrastructure.   
7.  Recognizing these problems, the  Government places the rehabilitation of key water 
infrastructure  facilities  as  a  top  national  priority.  At  the  same  time,  the  Government  is 
increasingly aware that the rehabilitation of I&D facilities must be planned and implemented with 
great care—not to repeat or extend the social and environmental damage caused by the rapid 
expansion of irrigation systems in the past. The Government also recognizes that the current 
practice of irrigation management is wasteful and  does not promote conservation, or higher 
productivity of water.  In 2001 the Government, with the assistance of the World Bank, prepared 
a strategy2 to rehabilitate and improve the basic irrigation infrastructure of the country. This 
strategy consists of a two-phase approach, involving a public investment program to rehabilitate 
and modernize  selected main and interfarm (i.e., secondary) irrigation systems as the first 
phase, and gradually shifting to improvement of the remaining interfarm and on-farm irrigation 
systems driven by private investment as a second phase.  
8.  More recently, the Government initiated several important reforms in the water sector. 
The  recent  Presidential  decree3 promotes  the  reorganization  of  the  country’s  irrigation 
management system from the current administrative and territorial  base to the river-basin 
system, and also calls for the introduction of market principles in the water delivery services in 
the country. The Presidential Decree of March 2003 also set a clear priority on establishing 
water users associations (WUAs) for delivering water and managing local irrigation works. It 
recognizes  the  need  to  improve  the  legal  framework  and  implementation  mechanisms  for

9.  Farm privatization is another high priority in the Government’s reform agenda. Despite 
substantial assistance provided by the Government in the form of subsidized inputs, credit lines, 
and farm debt relief, shirkats5 in the past few years had  a disappointing performance—they 
failed to increase crop yields and output and incurred financial losses. During 1996–2001, 
virtually  no  output  growth  was  observed  in  shirkats,  whereas  dekhan  and  private  farms 
experienced  significant  output  growth.6 Shirkats  could  not  provide  sufficient  incentives  to 
farmers to achieve higher productivity and efficiency and improve their living standards. Despite 
better performances of private and dekhan farms, the Government has been conservative in 
accelerating farm privatization. For instance, the Government carried out complete privatization 
only on loss-incurring shirkats; moreover, individual applicants for private land from shirkats 
often received low quality marginal land. Thus far, only about 8% of over 2,000 shirkats in the 
country have been fully privatized. The Government maintained that its policy of gradual and 
selective privatization is justified because it avoids the large social costs associated with high 
unemployment that may be caused by large-scale privatization.  
10.  The situation can rapidly change as the Government’s recent initiatives gave a new 
impetus to farm privatization and the restructuring process. The Presidential Decree of March 
2003 (footnote 3) for the first time explicitly recognized private farming as the model for future 
farming and expanded the private farmers’ status by awarding long-term land lease and formal 
registration. The most recent presidential decree7 approves the accelerated privatization of 
shirkats, which would eventually increase the share of private farms from the current 12.5% to 
63.3% of total cropland by 2007.  
11.  A  crucial  constraint  in  accelerating  farm  privatization  and  restructuring  is  the  farm 
support services for private farming. The existing agricultural support services do not meet the 
needs of  an increasing number of private farmers—in both quantity and quality, including 
access to input supply, and farm machinery. As a result, private farms remain dependent on 
shirkats. Currently, most of machinery services are provided by the so-called machinery and 
tractor  pools,  the  joint  stock  companies  with  significant  Government  shares.  These  pools 
provide services that are often costly, of poor quality, and not tailored to the needs of the newly

12.  Another  significant  barrier  in  reforming  the  agriculture  sector  is  the Government’s 
restrictive policies on pricing and procurement for cotton and wheat that continue to adversely 
affect  farmers’  incentives  to  increase  farm  productivity  and  efficiency.  The  Government’s

Agricultural Development Project of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)9 played a catalytic role 
in changing the Government’s policies toward reducing the mandatory procurement quota, and 
introducing more market-oriented pricing systems that favor farmers. As a result, prices of 
cotton and wheat increased by 57% and 72%, respectively. Similar reforms in the procurement 
system are being pursued under the World Bank’s Rural Enterprise Support Project. In addition, 
the Government issued a resolution in December 2002, allowing the private sector to participate 
in the wholesale purchase and export of cotton. The implementation and the impacts of this new 
resolution remain to be seen, however.  
13.  Lastly, Uzbekistan’s narrow base of crop farming that essentially centers on only two 
crops—cotton and wheat—needs attention. During the Soviet period, the practice to rotate 
cotton with alfalfa was common,10 as the latter provided the necessary additional nutrients to the 
soil and high-protein fodder for the livestock industry. After independence, this cropping practice 
practically ceased because of the Government’s policy of food security in wheat production11 
and the downturn of the livestock industry.12  Now cotton-winter wheat is the main crop rotation 
practice in Uzbekistan. From an economic and agronomic perspective the current cropping 
pattern that is based on cotton and wheat is likely sub-optimal. However, at present the options 
for crop diversification are limited. Given prevailing market conditions, farmers’ know-how, 
government policies and agro-ecological conditions it is unlikely that the current cropping 
pattern will change significantly over the short to medium term. Shift to higher value crops is

17.  Project Rationale. The Amu Zang irrigation  system is located in the  Surkhandarya 
Province, and comprises a cascade of pumping stations and the network of irrigation canals 
conveying water from the Amu Darya River to a command area of 96,800 ha.16  The system  
was built in 1973 and is the third largest irrigation system17 in the country. The system is at the 
end of its useful life, and the reliability and capacity of the aging pump cascade has declined 
seriously. Some 400,000 people live in the five districts covered by Amu Zang irrigation system, 
and their livelihood depends primarily on irrigated agriculture since the industry and service 
sectors are less developed than they are in other parts of Uzbekistan. Poverty incidence in the 
project area is estimated at 31.4%, compared with the national average of 27.5%. Unless a 
major overhaul occurs, some of the key components of the main system could collapse in less 
than 5 years. The people in the  project area are  caught in a vicious cycle of deteriorating 
irrigation service, falling income, and land degradation. If the system is not rehabilitated, it would 
lose much of its operational functions, reducing its irrigation service area by as much as 50% in 
10 years. Most villagers would then be forced to abandon cultivation, without prospects of 
finding alternative livelihood. This will also have major environmental consequences such as 
large-scale land degradation and desertification.  
18.  The proposed Project will help the villagers in the Surkhandarya Province break free 
from the persisting vicious cycle of worsening poverty—by providing them with an improved 
irrigation system, and also by stimulating growth, and promoting sustainable and profitable 
agriculture through a range of interventions, such as farm privatization, choice of cropping 
patterns, and marketing of outputs. ADB is well placed to capture this opportunity, as it has 
played a catalytic role in introducing the first major agriculture reform in Uzbekistan through the 
Ak Altin Agricultural Development Project.18 The proposed Project also offers an opportunity for 
ADB  to  help  transform  the  present  irrigation  management  style  to  a  demand-driven and 
beneficiary-led irrigation operation, and promote stronger accountability and efficiency of water 
institutions. Altogether, these initiatives will help Uzbekistan move toward achieving sustainable 
and more efficient  use of land and water resources. Replication of pilot initiatives proposed 
under the Project will also bring about significant positive impacts on the management of shared 
water in the Amu Darya Basin as a whole.

1.  Rehabilitation of Amu Zang Irrigation System 
22.  The Project will support the cost-effective and prioritized rehabilitation of the Amu Zang 
irrigation system by (i) constructing a new sediment control facility; (ii) selectively rehabilitating 
the  pumps, motors,  and  other  auxiliary  facilities  in  the  three  main  pumping  stations;  (iii) 
improving  the  maintenance  facilities;  and  (iv)  rehabilitating selected sections  of  the  main 
irrigation and drainage network.  
23.  A new sediment control facility will be constructed to reduce the amount of sediment 
entering the canal network and to extend the operational life of the pumping stations. The works 
on the main pumping stations will include replacement of two pumps/motor units of pumping 
station Amu Zang I, rehabilitation of the auxiliary systems of pumping stations Amu Zang I and 
II, and comprehensive rehabilitation of the Babatag pumping station to improve the performance 
of pump stations.  Further, the Project will support the refurbishment  of  four  maintenance 
workshops to facilitate the continued operation of the pumping stations after the rehabilitation. 
The Project will also rehabilitate selected sections of the main irrigation canals to restore the 
system’s original water conveyance capacity and ensure efficient and timely distribution of 
irrigation water.  
2.  Support to Improve Irrigation Management 
24.  The Project will improve the management systems of Amu Zang irrigation system and 
Amu-Surkhan Basin Irrigation Organization (ASBIO) by  (i) strengthening their capacities; (ii) 
introducing improved O&M procedures,19 (iii) supporting the establishment of WUAs, and (iv) 
developing and installing a decision support system comprising a supervisory control and data 
acquisition (SCADA) system and an optimized water resources management model.  
25.  The  Project  will  support  capacity  building  for  ASBIO  by  organizing  training  for 
managerial  staff  on  the  new  procedures  for  effective  O&M  of  the  system  and  on  WUA 
development. The Project will also provide direct support to formation and operation of seven 
WUAs in five project districts and training and advisory services to more than 50 WUAs in the 
project province. The SCADA system will be installed to monitor, control, and automate the 
operation of the system.  Also, a computer model will be developed to improve the planning and 
efficient use of the basin’s water resources. The model will simulate and optimize the operation 
of reservoirs, pumping stations, and the distribution of water to canals and various users.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Expected Impacts 
1.  Economic Impacts 
52.  Analyses were carried out to assess the economic viability of the Project and financial 
viability of the participating farms. The main quantifiable benefits of the investment come from (i) 
protection from production losses that may occur due to further deterioration and possible failure 
of the system in case the Project does not materialize, and (ii) modest increases in yield and 
cropping intensity resulting from a more reliable irrigation water supply and the ongoing reform 
in the agriculture sector. While the proposed reform measures (paras. 30, 82 and 83) will have a 
positive impact on economic returns, these have not been quantified due to methodological 
difficulties and data uncertainties.  
53.  Without the Project, a declining water supply from increasingly inefficient pumps will 
have a negative impact on crop yields and the cultivated area. The impact will be greater for the 
Babatag canal than for canals above Amu Zang I and II pumping stations. Overall, the average 
yield of cotton will decline from the present 2.7 tons per hectare (t/ha) to 2.3 t/ha, but wheat 
yield will remain unchanged at 3.1 t/ha since it is grown during winter and spring when the total 
demand for irrigation is low.  The average cropping intensity over the whole project area will fall 
to 91% from the present 110%, equivalent to a decline in cultivated area of 18,400 ha per year.  
With the Project, the average cotton yield will increase from 2.8 to 3.4 t/ha, the wheat yield from 
3.1 to 3.9 t/ha, and the overall cropping intensity to 123%, equivalent to an additional 13,500 ha 
of crops grown each year. The output of cotton will increase from 114,000 tons to 136,000 tons 
and wheat production will rise from 128,000 tons to 165,000 tons in year 10. These are 
conservative assumptions compared with the best practice found among project area farmers. 
54.  Benefits also accrue from the reduced pumping costs for water and savings of O&M 
costs for maintaining the system. The greater efficiency of new pumps will reduce the cost of 
energy for pumping by an estimated $495,000 per year (in economic prices). Implementation of 
the facility to reduce the intake of sediments to the system will reduce wear and tear on pumps 
and lower the cost of desilting main canals by $250,000 per year. O&M costs for the pumping 
stations are estimated to decline by $95,000 per year with the Project. 
55.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the Project is 19.5% and the economic 
net present value (NPV) at the discount rate of 12% is $51.7 million. Sensitivity analysis was 
carried out on the effects of key variables on the economic viability of the Project. Overall, the 
EIRR was robust and well above the acceptable minimum (12%) despite the adverse effects of 
price and yield declines, project benefit delays, and investment cost increases. A risk analysis of 
key sensitivity variables gave a standard deviation of 3.1% from the base EIRR and a less than 
1% probability of the EIRR falling below 12%.

15 
56.  To illustrate the financial viability of farms in the project area, farm budget analysis was 
carried out for three types of farms: shirkats,  private farms, and dekhan farms. The results 
suggest that the Project will lead to increased incomes for farm households.  The project impact 
is expected to be least on shirkats and greatest for private farms.  Net incomes for shirkats will 
rise from about $180 per ha now to $210 per ha by year 5 and $260 by year 10.  Incomes for 
private farms, with crop diversification and improved productivity will increase from less than 
$125 per ha now, to $250 ha in year 5 and $360 per ha in year 10.  For dekhan farms, the 
expected increase is from around $740 per ha now to $970 per ha in year 10. 
57.  The  financial  sustainability  of  the  proposed  ASCs  was  also  analyzed.  The  result 
suggests that ASCs are expected to yield a robust financial internal rate of return (FIRR) of 
25.9%. Over 25 years the NPV of income streams would be $478,000 at a discount rate of 12%. 
The benefit distribution and poverty impact analysis was also carried out for the Project. It 
yielded a poverty impact ratio of 0.46.  Since this is above the poverty incidence ratio of 0.31, 
poor households will benefit relatively more from the Project than the other stakeholder groups. 
Further information on economic and financial analyses is in Appendix 8 and in Supplementary 
Appendix G. 
58.  The irrigated agriculture operations in the Amu Zang area—as in most other irrigated 
systems  in  Uzbekistan—are  heavily  distorted  by  implicit  taxes  as  well  as  subsidies.  The 
Government, through its mandatory state procurement system for cotton and wheat at lower 
prices, imposes heavy implicit taxes on farmers surrounding the Amu Zang irrigation system.  
On the other hand, the Government also provides direct and indirect subsidies to farmers in the 
form of cheap electricity, O&M of pumps and main canals, subsidized fuel, fertilizers and 
machinery operations, and low interest credits on farm operations. The comparisons of taxes 
and subsidies involving the Amu Zang irrigation system shows that, on the whole, the total 
amount of taxes imposed on the farming community in the Amu Zang area ($33.2 million) 
exceeds  the  total  subsidies  ($24.4  million)  provided  by  the  Government.  This  finding  is 
consistent with World Bank’s recent analysis that the net resource transfer out of the agriculture 
sector over the past decade has been significant.24 
59.  According  to  ADB’s  subsidies  policy,25 the  existing  subsidies  are  justifiable  on  the 
ground that they have offsetting effects on the Government’s heavy implicit taxing system on 
farmers in the Amu Zang area, and also that the market institutions are weak in this transition 
economy. However, ADB’s subsidies policy also encourages the systematic phasing out of 
subsidies as they create sector inefficiency and farm disincentives. The Government’s recent 
policies of reducing both subsidies and implicit taxes through continuous increases in key input 
prices as well as in outputs are important26 and should be encouraged. The reform measures—
introduction of water delivery fees, implementation of sustainable cost recovery policies, and 
promotion of private sector-driven rural institutions such as ASCs and WUAs—proposed in the 
Project are expected to further reduce the farming subsidies in the Amu Zang area. Meantime 
the proposed reductions in the Government procurement quota for cotton  and wheat in the 
Project districts are also expected to reduce the implicit taxes imposed on farmers through 
higher farmgate prices. Subsidies and taxes are discussed in detail in Appendix 8.

2.  Impact on the Environment 
60.  The  Project  will  have  a  significant  positive  environmental  impact  on  the  areas 
surrounding the Amu Zang irrigation system. The new sediment control facility will reduce by 
50% the sediments entering the system by 50% and the rehabilitated main canals and control 
structures will reduce water losses and infiltration and improve water availability. Improvements 
to the drainage system will reduce waterlogging and soil salinity.   
61.   The project rehabilitation works will be concentrated around the existing large pumping 
stations and the contractors will use the existing buildings. Special clauses in the contract 
documents  will  ensure  that  the  technical  operations  (replacement  of  pumps,  motors,  and 
construction activities) are carried out according to the standard Government procedures for the 
appropriate  disposal  of  waste,  minimization  of  nuisances  during  construction,  and  proper 
aftercare of the construction sites.  The contractors will also comply with national health, safety, 
and hygiene requirements, which will be incorporated in the contract documents. Attention will 
be paid to social discipline, control, and safeguards on wastewater and solid waste.  
62.  The Project will not build new canals. Neither will it expand pumping capacity or the 
irrigated area. Therefore, no resettlement or land acquisition will be required. The Project is not 
expected to give rise to significant negative environmental impacts.  Measures have been 
proposed to mitigate the minor potential negative impacts identified in the initial environmental 
examination (IEE) and costs for implementing the measures were included in the project 
budget.  The main mitigating measures include (i) monitoring the morphology of the Amu Darya 
River, (ii) studying the need for fish exclusion devices at the intake, (iii) building safeguards into 
the  contract  documents  to  cover  the  handling  and  disposal  of  hazardous  materials27 by 
contractors, and (iv) preparing a plan to clean up existing stockpiles of obsolete agrochemicals.  
63.  At present the riparian states have no formal multilateral water-sharing agreements on 
Amu Darya River. The only existing agreement between Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan is to 
equally share the water flow of Amu Darya River between the two countries at point Kerk 
downstream of the Amu Zang irrigation system. The Project will not increase the intake of river 
water; instead, rehabilitation of the irrigation system and the resultant improvement in water use 
efficiency will allow about 5% reduction in the consumption of irrigation water28 and reduce the 
amount of drainage effluent going back to the river system. Thus, the proposed Project will not 
have any impact on the neighboring (upstream and downstream) countries in terms of water- 
sharing arrangements, water intake limits, and transboundary environmental consequences.

3.      Impact on Living Standards 
a.  Poverty Reduction 
65.  Some 400,000 people live in the area of the Amu Zang irrigation system, 88% of whom 
live in the rural areas. The detailed description of the project area is in Supplementary Appendix 
A. A World Bank poverty study (2003) estimated that in 2000, 28.4% of the population of 
Surkhandarya Province had incomes below the poverty line.29 The feasibility study carried out 
the detailed project area-specific social and poverty analysis (using a methodology similar to 
that in the World Bank study). The details on the approach used are in Appendix 9. The result 
suggests that poverty incidence in the project area was 31.4%. This percentage is equivalent to 
130,000 people or about 16,500 households. 30 About 44% of the poor in the project area reside 
in Djarkurgan and Kumkurgan districts; 39% in the remote Muzrabad district; and 22% and 23% 
in Angor and Termez districts, respectively.31 The poor comprise 43% of shirkat workers and 
31.6% of dekhan farmers. There are no poor among private farmers although many are 
vulnerable in the sense that their incomes are just above the poverty line and even minor 
shocks can cause them to easily slide down to poverty.   
66.  The Project will contribute to poverty reduction in the project sites by improving the 
reliability of irrigation water supplies to 96,800 ha of irrigated land. This benefit will accrue to 
some 400,000 people of whom 126,000 are poor. Because of the poor condition of the irrigation 
systems, only cotton fields are provided about 100% of their irrigation water quota. Farms 
producing wheat are given 70–90% of their irrigation water quota, while other cash crops grown 
on household plots receive only 40–70% of their quota. Poor farmers who often grow crops 
other than cotton thus get less water. With overall improvement in irrigation system as a result 
of the Project, the poor farmers will benefit directly.  
67.  In Uzbekistan, rural income and poverty are related to availability of irrigation water. 
Findings of a 2003 World Bank study32 show that due to the arid conditions of the country, 
converting its irrigated agriculture land to nonirrigated land can reduce the income of farm 
households by more than 30%. The study compared the farm profitability of an irrigated and 
rain-fed land. The income effect would be more severe in steppe zones. The study also noted 
that in south Uzbekistan, a 10% decrease in farm income would increase poverty incidence by 
14.3%. Thus, if the Amu Zang irrigation system is not rehabilitated and is left to deteriorate at its 
present pace, poverty incidence in the area could increase from the current 31.4% to 44%. In 
the Babatag canal command area where alternative sources of irrigation are unavailable, 
poverty rate would rise to more than 50%. With the Project, however, irrigation water will be 
supplied to a large number of farmer-beneficiaries, including the poor and vulnerable farm 
households (headed by women and minorities). This would reduce poverty incidence from 
31.4% to 25%.

b.  Gender and Development 
71.  The Project will be beneficial to women. For women who serve as heads of family and 
who own land, access to a more regular supply of water for irrigation will improve their yield, 
encourage more cropping intensity, and increase their income. Production in their household 
plots will also improved. Women who take care of these plots will produce more cash crops to 
increase their purchasing power  and enable them to pay for more nutritious food and other 
essential needs of their household. Moreover, improved access to machinery through more 
effective ASCs will significantly reduce the agricultural work performed by women and children 
manually in the fields. Women can therefore devote more time to their household plots for cash 
crop production; the children, on the other hand, will be able to attend school more regularly. 
With  40%  of  the  respondents  stating  that  women  should  not  participate  in  agriculture 
management, the Project will develop measures that will increase the capacity of women to get 
more involved in project activities, especially in the development of the WUAs. The gender 
action plan is in Supplementary Appendix J. 
c.  Institutional Development 
72.  The Project will contribute to institutional development by establishing WUAs that will be 
managed and operated by the local communities. While the objective of the WUA is to ensure 
the sustainable use and management of the rehabilitated irrigation systems, in the long term 
successful WUAs can serve as models for community-driven activities that capitalize on the 
social capital networks to address and resolve local issues, especially those that will impact on 
poverty.

B.  Risks and Safeguards  
75.  A number of risks may affect project implementation. Achieving sustainable O&M lies at 
the heart of the project rationale and design, and remains the main risk in achieving objectives. 
Failure may result from an inadequate operation framework for WUAs, insufficient organization 
and training of WUAs, lack of proper water delivery fee systems, or limited capacity of the 
beneficiaries to pay. To mitigate these risks, the Project is proposing a range of activities: (i) 
developing of a national policy on cost recovery and improved operational procedures for WUAs 
development, (ii) improved O&M practices at the Amu Zang irrigation system and ASBIO, (iii) 
introducing water delivery fees in the project province, and (iv) developing WUAs to address the 
on-farm and interfarm O&M. These cost recovery measures will be accompanied by reduced 
Government procurement quotas on cotton and wheat for farmers in the Project area. The 
increased farm incomes from such a measure will enable farmers to pay their water delivery 
fees. Progress in developing an adequate cost recovery framework will be closely monitored 
under the Project. Notwithstanding such development, the Government also recognized that its 
budget allocation has not been adequate, and assured the timely and full provision of O&M 
budget for the irrigation system.  
76.  Lack of participation by farmer beneficiaries in the development of the cost-recovery 
scheme may lead to default in farmers’ payments. To minimize this risk, close consultations with 
farmer  beneficiaries  were  conducted  at  every  stage  of  project  preparation,  including 
presentation of the estimated per hectare costs of on-farm rehabilitation.

AGRICULTURE AND WATER SECTOR ANALYSIS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  In Uzbekistan 10% of the land area is cultivable and of the cultivable area of 4.8 million 
hectares (ha), 88% is irrigated. Irrigated agriculture accounts for 35% of the gross domestic 
product, 35% of foreign exchange receipts, and 45% of employment. The most important crop is 
cotton, which accounts for about 30% of export earnings or about $1 billion annually. Since 
independence from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the Government has found it difficult 
to allocate sufficient resources for irrigation system maintenance. However, it is now taking 
steps  to  increase  investment  in  the  sector,  rehabilitate  irrigation  and  drainage  (I&D) 
infrastructure, and improve farm sustainability. 
2.  The agriculture development strategy centers on three strategic goals to: (i) generate 
foreign exchange earnings, (ii) improve food security, and (iii) promote rural employment and 
improve living standards. Achievement of these goals depends on the transformation to a 
competitive, market-oriented rural economy. In 2000 the Government outlined an action plan for 
2001–2003 for economic reforms in agriculture that emphasizes promoting farm and enterprise 
privatization,  improving  agricultural  financial  systems, building central and local institutional 
capacity, improving irrigation and drainage infrastructure, and relaxing Government restrictions 
on pricing and state crop procurement. A recent presidential decree reaffirmed these goals,1 
including recognition of the important role of private farms, improved technology, institutional 
restructuring focusing on a new basin-oriented irrigation management system, and greater 
dependence on market principles in agriculture and irrigation at all levels. 
B.  Agriculture and Land Policies 
1.  Procurement and Pricing  
3.  Several regulations remaining from the former centrally planned system have distorted 
agricultural production. Of these, the most important has been the system of annual State 
orders to agricultural enterprises and farms for the production of cotton and wheat.  In 2001 the 
Government  agreed  to  test  reforms  to  this  system2  centered  on  (i)  abolishing  or  easing  
production targets, (ii) reducing the mandatory crop procurement quotas, (iii) abolishing joint 
responsibility for procurement quotas, (iv) adjusting of state procurement prices based on 
changes in international prices and domestic inflation, and (v) gradually reducing in the state 
procurement of wheat and cotton. In 2002 the Government extended these reforms nationwide 
and also limited wheat and cotton procurement by the state purchasing agencies to 50% of a 
farm’s production, with the producer being able to sell the remainder at will.3 Further, the March 
2003  Presidential  decree  (footnote  1)  abolishes the State-directed crop production targets 
beyond the 2003 season and confirms that the mandatory State procurement of raw cotton and 
grain will not exceed 50% of actual production.    
4.  Under the State order system, farmgate prices were based on expenditure norms for 
crop production rather than on world market prices. Combined with an overvalued currency,

2.  Privatization of Agricultural Enterprises 
5.  There  are  at  present  three  main  types  of  agricultural  producers:  (i)  cooperative 
agricultural enterprises (shirkats), (ii) private farms, and (iii) dekhan farms (household plots). 
The shirkats and private farms are State regulated and have been subject to the State order 
system. Despite substantial financial assistance provided by the Government, shirkat farms 
have performed rather poorly, failing to increase yields and output and incurring financial losses. 
Private farms have generally performed better. The Government is therefore strengthening the 
legal and enabling environment for the development of private and dekhan farms. Private farms 
were first created in 1992, but most date from 1996 or later. This number is increasing rapidly. 
The establishment of private farms within shirkat farms is a district-level decision, but the 
conversion of a whole shirkat to private farms requires a decision from the Cabinet.  When this 
occurs, the water management activities are taken over by water users associations (WUAs). 
6.  The Government has supported private farming with 50–year inheritable land use rights, 
low-interest loans, exemption from value added tax (VAT) for fuel and fertilizer, and favorable 
terms for machinery purchase. However,  private farms have often been formed from loss-
incurring shirkats or by allocation of marginal land and they must often rely on shirkats for their 
input supply, farm machinery rental, and irrigation water.  State orders for cotton and grain and 
lack of access to Government’s advance credit system have hampered the performance of 
private farms.  Furthermore, land cannot be used as collateral with the banks.  By the end of 
2002, 155 shirkats had been converted to private farms, while 1,877 remained.  This slow pace 
of privatization has not been consistent with the Government’s own long-term strategic objective 
of increasing agricultural efficiency and output. However, the Presidential decree of 24 March 
2003  explicitly  recognizes,  for  the  first  time,  the  importance  of  private  farms  and  market 
principles and should result in expanding the privatization process. 
7.  Support services, especially for private farms, are inadequate at present. There is a 
need to strengthen the provision of support services for private farms, especially regarding 
access to crop inputs, machinery, irrigation services, credit, and markets. 
C.  Water Resource Policies 
1.  Water Resources and Irrigation 
8.  Uzbekistan is situated in the basins of the Syrdarya and Amudarya rivers, which together 
form the Aral Sea basin. The annual limit of water available to Uzbekistan under international 
agreements is 63.02 cubic kilometers (km³), which is more than 5 times the 11.53 km³ annual 
internal renewable water resources of the country. The reliable flow available to Uzbekistan in 
years of low water is 54.2 km³,  of which 49.0 km³ is available for irrigation.

9.  Inefficient use of water compounds the problems of limited availability.  Although official 
figures indicate over 60% irrigation efficiency, in many cases as little as 40% of the water 
diverted by irrigation systems reaches the plants. The rest is lost in the irrigation system and in 
the field. As a result, drainage flows amount to half of the water taken in. Drainage water is 
reused in some cases—particularly where irrigation water supply shortages occur—even though 
this may lead to salinization of land. 
10.  Between 1970 and 1990, irrigation in Uzbekistan underwent spectacular development 
with the total irrigated area increasing from 2.6 to 4.2 million ha. This rate of increase was only 
possible under a strong set of institutions in the field of design and construction and an equally 
strong  institutional  framework  for  the  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  the  system. 
Maintaining I&D infrastructure of this magnitude requires substantial expenditures for both O&M 
and capital replacement. Since independence Uzbekistan has not been able to keep up with the 
annual financial requirements, and expenditures in the water sector have been declining in real 
terms. Furthermore, due to the low profitability of  farming, on-farm I&D systems are also in poor 
condition.  
11.  One estimate4 has placed the minimum cost of an irrigation rehabilitation investment 
program in the next  15 years at $3.9 billion or $260 million annually. This amounts to about  
$920 per ha over 15 years, with about 54% of all investment requirements being for on-farm 
infrastructure. Since the farms are responsible for maintaining most of the on-farm irrigation and 
part of the drainage infrastructure, this implies an additional farm income requirement of up to 
$140 million annually. 
12.  Two thirds of all irrigated areas in the country require pumping to heights in the range of 
5–150 meters. As the price of electricity is increased toward its long-run marginal cost, the rising 
cost of pumping water will need to be counterbalanced by policies to sustain the long-term 
future of irrigated agriculture through reduced consumption.  
2.  Operation and Maintenance and Cost Recovery 
13.  The Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources (MAWR) is responsible for preparing 
the annual budget for irrigation O&M. In the final budget allocations, salaries and electricity have 
priority over other cost components. There are no specific water delivery charges at present, but 
shirkats and private farmers are responsible for on-farm O&M costs. The State does levy a 
“unified tax” on  farms, which in theory includes a small charge for water use. This tax averages 
about $9 per ha in the project area.  
14.  Government budget expenditures for irrigation O&M in 2002 were about $130 million. By 
MAWR estimates, however, the annual requirement for O&M and depreciation is $550 million. 
Of this about 46%, or about $48 per ha, on average, is estimated to be on-farm costs. These 
estimates do not fully consider energy prices and with an economic price for energy 3 times 
greater than its current financial cost, this may add $200 million per year to O&M. 
15.  The Government intends to gradually implement a system of payment for water along 
with the establishment of WUAs, but at present there are no detailed cost recovery and water 
delivery policy and implementation plans. A cost recovery policy and implementation plan 
should be developed after further economic analysis of costs and farmers’ ability to pay and 
should be based on sound principles regarding (i) which costs are the responsibility of farmers,

D.  Water Sector Legal and Institutional Arrangements 
1.  Legal Basis for Water Use 
16.  The most important legal document governing water use is the Law of the Republic of 
Uzbekistan on Water and Water Usage, 6 May 1993, with later amendments. Water is State 
property, subject to rational use and protected by the State. Off-farm irrigation infrastructure is 
owned by the State. On-farm facilities are owned by the shirkats, or by associations that have 
assumed their rights and obligations. Entities that have been granted isolated (primary) usage of 
water have the obligation to permit other entities and citizens secondary water usage, by 
agreement with MAWR and the State Committee on Nature Conservation. This appears to 
provide a legal basis for the regulation of water deliveries between a WUA and its members.  
17.  The Cabinet of Ministers has jurisdiction to establish a procedure for paying for water 
usage  and  compensation  for  polluting  and  exhausting  water  resources.  Water  users  are 
encouraged to carry out irrigation and land improvement work and the Land Code provides for 
tax,  loan,  and  other  advantages  to  those  who  introduce  efficient  and  resource-saving 
technologies.  
2.  National Institutions 
18.  The most important central institution in the field of irrigation and drainage is MAWR.  
MAWR was formed in 1997 by the merger of the Ministry of Melioration and Water Management 
and the Ministry of Agriculture. MAWR  has offices at central, province, and district levels. It is 
currently being restructured and reorganized and its new role5 includes (i) formulating policies, 
(ii) improving and introducing modern technology, and (iii) coordinating agencies and service 
enterprises that should perform on market-based principles. In addition, a fundamental change 
is  being  made  at  the  local  level  with  the  introduction  of  a  basin-based  water  resources 
management system and market principles in irrigation water management (para. 15). Also, the 
overall structure will be streamlined and decentralized to provincial, district, and basin levels.  
19.  The water resource management department of MAWR is expected to refocus its efforts 
and be more effective in policy development, regulation, and other priority areas of irrigation and 
water resource management.6 Eventually, MAWR may need to clearly separate between water 
resources management activities and irrigation service activities to carry out these functions in a 
professional and neutral manner.

20.  MAWR will need to establish a unit at either the central or provincial level to monitor,

3.  Local Institutions 
21.  Until June 2003, the institutional structure of water management was essentially the 
same as before independence, except that the provincial and district authorities now dealt with 
shirkats and a growing number of private farms. This institutional structure had, however, been 
weakened by the reduced investment in O&M and irrigation development. Water resources 
decision making and management were inefficient and sometimes governed by administrative 
rather than technical concerns. 
22.  To address the various inefficiencies in the water management system, the Government 
has  begun  restructuring  the  irrigation  subsector.  Following  reorganization,  the  local  water 
management structure will be based on 10 river basins (hydrological units) rather than on the 
current  administrative  boundaries.  The  change  will  help  rationalize  the  planning  and 
implementation of water allocation among both irrigation systems and other water users. The 
formation of basin irrigation system organizations will result in (i) better and more efficient 
decision making for water management, (ii) reduced administrative and management costs, (iii) 
improved water use efficiency, and (iv) a greater capacity to introduce integrated water resource 
management. Although basin irrigation system organizations will focus primarily on irrigation 
management, they will also be responsible for allocating of water to other uses and for water 
quality.  Consideration  is  being  given  to  the  formation  of  two  councils  for  each  basin 
organization: a water allocation council with representatives from various sectors (to ensure 
transparency  in  water  allocation),  and  a  technical  council.  Basin  organizations  would  be 
responsible for implementing the national water allocation priorities for (i) domestic use, (ii) 
power generation, (iii) industrial use, and (iv) irrigation.  
23.  Under the new arrangements, issues that will need to be addressed will include (i) 
supporting the development of policies and regulations for WUAs, (ii) investing in off-farm and 
on-farm systems to improve water management, (iii) developing policies and procedures for the 
basin irrigation organizations, (iv) introducing integrated water management in the river basins 
along with setting up the basin irrigation organizations, and (v) developing a strong extension 
service and research and development programs to support improvements in on-farm irrigation. 
24.  The Government plans to use this reorganization as an opportunity for major corporate 
restructuring in the irrigation sector and it is now in the process of reducing the number of water 
sector  institutions  to  70.  After  the  reorganization,  the  provincial  and  district  water  and 
agricultural departments will still play a limited role as water service providers, although their 
ultimate role remains unclear. A critical need in the reorganization will be to coordinate the new 
organizations after reorganizing local water management responsibilities.

4.  Water User Associations 
25.  An  important  aspect  of  the  reforms  and  reorganization  in  the  water  sector  is  the 
promotion of WUAs to assume responsibility for on-farm7 water management and O&M.  WUAs 
are developing rapidly as they are seen as the only option for managing water resources at this 
level. 
26.  Under a decree of  5 January 20028 on the reorganization of unprofitable agricultural 
enterprises, provision is made for establishing self-supporting WUAs. WUAs are joint stock 
organizations owned by the farmers and are exempt for 2 years, from payment of VAT and 
income and property taxes.  Under this decree, irrigation infrastructure on the reorganized farm 
becomes the property of the WUA and the inter-farm irrigation structures are transferred to the 
territorial divisions of MAWR.   
27.  The Government has a clear priority to establish WUAs to ensure sound water resource 
management, rational use of water, and O&M management of local I&D infrastructure. To date 
268 WUAs are in operation. A number of issues need to be clarified regarding their operations, 
and in due time the legal basis for WUAs may need to be strengthened. Issues that need to be 
clarified include (i) the status of WUAs with regard to water rights and taxation; (ii) area of 
operation, size and definition of infrastructure and equipment for which WUAs are responsible; 
(iii) status and organization of various farm types and other water users within the WUA area; 
(iv)  responsibility  for  collecting  and  using  water  charges;  (v)  transfer  of  ownership  of 
infrastructure; and (vi) the necessary conditions for establishing WUA federations. 
28.  Various developments favor the establishment of WUAs. In 2000 and 2001, which were 
drought years, the main focus of  MAWR’s activities was on improving water delivery services 
and promoting the idea of WUAs. Starting from 2000, every region established a demonstration 
farm to model an effective WUA for the purpose of training regional irrigation engineers. Drought 
also  exposed  problems  with  water  distribution  and  measurement.  As  a  result,  MAWR 
rehabilitated a large number of water measuring hydroposts at the on-farm level and established 
on-farm water accounting practices. MOF also relaxed the arrangements for  financing the crops 
procured for State needs to make an explicit provision for allowing farms to use allocated 
advances to finance the activities of their water user groups.

O&M policy, (ii) institutional development of WUAs, and (iii) the development of a mechanism

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR SUPPORT TO POLICY AND INSTITUTIONAL 
REFORMS IN THE WATER SECTOR 
 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will support the Government of Uzbekistan in implementing 
policy and institutional reforms in the water sector by (i) strengthening the newly reorganized 
institutions at national, basin, and provincial levels, (ii) providing policy advice, and (iii) developing 
policy and legal documents related to water sector management.  
 
2.  The TA will have two components: (i) policy and institutional reforms and capacity building 
support at the national level, and (ii) institutional and capacity building support at the basin and 
province levels. The first component will assist the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources 
(MAWR) to (i) enhance its policy development capacity; (ii) develop key policy and strategy 
documents  on  cost  recovery,  water  delivery  fees,  and  water  users  association  (WUA) 
development; (iii) advise the Government on institutional and policy reform options; and (iv) 
support the establishment of the Water Sector Reform Unit within the Technology and Dispatch 
Service of MAWR to promote water sector reform initiatives. The second component will assist 
Amu-Surkhan Basin Irrigation Organization (ASBIO) and Surkhandarya Province Agricultural and 
Water  Department  (SPAWD)  to  (i)  develop  detailed  functional  procedures  of  the  newly 
established ASBIO, (ii) strengthen the capacity of ASBIO and SPAWD to develop basin water 
management plan and implement the cost recovery policy at the basin level, and (iii) promote 
WUA development in Surkhandarya Province.  
 
3.  The components will complement and support the activities under the Amu Zang Irrigation 
Rehabilitation  Project  (loan),  which  will  include  direct  assistance  for  establishing  and 
strengthening WUAs in the project pilot areas.  The loan project will assist the WUAs in the pilot 
areas by (i) providing technical and legal advisory services to WUAs, (ii) training WUA staff and 
others directly involved in their operation, and (iii) providing equipment necessary for WUA 
operations during the project implementation period. Activities under the TA and the loan will 
need to be well coordinated. 
 
B.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  The TA will require a total of 48 person-months of consulting services: 10 international 
and 38 domestic. The international consultants (person-months in parentheses) will comprise the 
team leader/water management specialist (3), legal and institutional development specialist (3), 
training specialist  (3), and unallocated portion  (1). The domestic consultants will comprise the 
deputy team leader/water management specialist (18), WUA development specialist (6), legal 
specialist (6), operation and maintenance (O&M) specialist (6), and unallocated portion (2). The 
TA consultants’ team will be based in Tashkent and will serve for 18 months. 
 
5.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will select1 and engage a suitably qualified firm of 
international  consultants  with  domestic  associates  to  provide  services,  following  ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging 
domestic consultants. The consultants will work closely with the  project management office 
(PMO) and project implementation unit (PIU) of the Amu Zang Irrigation Rehabilitation Project,

A.  Introduction 
1.  Economic and financial analyses were carried out to assess the economic viability of the 
Project and financial viability of the participating farms. The main feature of the Project is the 
pumping of water from the Amu Darya River through a cascade of three pumping stations to 
irrigate  farms  in  an  area  where  agriculture  would  otherwise  not  be  possible.  The  main 
quantifiable benefits of the investment come, first, from the prevention of losses of production in 
the future without the project and, second, from modest increases in production with the assured 
supply of water to farms in the future with the Project. While the proposed reform measures will 
have a positive impact on the economic viability of the Project, these measures were not 
incorporated in the analysis as the actual benefits accruing from them are difficult to quantify. 
Implementation of the Project will allow farmers to take advantage of other changes in the 
agriculture sector, including the relaxation of mandatory production quotas for wheat and cotton, 
and active promotion of private and dekhan farms. 
2.  The impact of the Project will be primarily on agricultural production. Estimating the 
project benefits was based on crop and farm budgets drawn up to reflect the conditions 
prevailing in the area. Without the Project, reductions in water supplied by the irrigation system 
will  have  significant  negative  impacts  on  yields  and  the  area  cultivated.  With  the  Project, 
changes  in  farm  production  depend  on  farmers’  responses  to  changes  in  the  farm 
environment—reliable  water  supply,  more  efficient  and  effective  use  of  water,  more  open 
markets and higher returns, opportunities for crop diversification, and reduced costs through 
increased productivity. Project implementation will benefit the livelihoods of all households in the 
project area; without the Project, livelihoods will be adversely affected because of the lack of 
alternative employment in the area.

22.  The subsidies paper11 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) encourages two policies: 
(i) subsidies should be transparent, and (ii) subsidies should be reduced or eliminated in a 
systematic manner unless they can be justified. The proposed project interventions are in line 
with  these  policies.  The  implicit  subsidies  (and  taxes)  involved  in  the  Project  have  been 
quantified and discussed. The specific policy measures promoted under the Project will reduce 
the implicit subsidies and taxes in the project area and beyond. For instance, the proposed 
reductions in the State mandatory quota for cotton and wheat at fixed prices in the five project 
districts will reduce the implicit taxes imposed on farmers’ output, which will give the farmers the 
real opportunity to  pay a significant part of the Amu Zang system’s O&M  costs. This move will 
also reduce the subsidies on cotton credit, since the cotton output beyond the mandatory quota 
is not eligible for subsidized advanced credit. Also, the proposed introduction of water delivery 
fees in five project districts will reduce the Government’s direct financing of the system’s O&M 
costs. The proposed loan project (through its associated technical assistance)  is expected to 
assist the Government in developing a national cost recovery policy, which will have a much 
greater impact in reducing the overall subsidies on irrigated agriculture in the long term, since 
the core of the expected policy is to gradually shift O&M responsibilities from the central 
Government to regional authorities and eventually to beneficiaries through the development of 
WUAs.  
23.  ADB’s paper on subsidies discusses five conditions when subsidies are justifiable: (i) 
when a project produces positive externalities, where social returns from a project exceed 
private returns; (ii) in decreasing cost sectors, where individual producers need to be subsidized 
to attain a socially optimal level of output; (iii) when other distortions or the effects of other 
government interventions have to be offset through subsidies; (iv) a case of redistribution, where 
subsidies are targeted at reducing poverty; and (v) in the context of transitional economies, 
where weakly developed market institutions make the subsidies unavoidable. It can be argued 
that conditions (iii) and (v) above are especially applicable to the Amu Zang Project. The 
Government currently imposes heavy output taxes for farmers in the project area through the 
cotton and wheat procurement system, which will cause the complete collapse of farming 
without counterbalancing subsidy schemes. Also, the rural market institutions in the transitional 
economy of Uzbekistan are weak and often absent (for instance there are no viable rural finance 
institutions  or  farm  machinery  services),  a  situation  that  necessitates  to  a  certain  extent 
Government  subsidies  and  support.  The  subsidies  involved  in  the  Amu  Zang  Irrigation 
Rehabilitation Project are justifiable on these grounds. However, the more important aspect of 
the proposed Project is that it will promote further reductions in subsidies as well as implicit 
taxes in the Amu Zang area through specific policy measures. For instance, the subsidies 
related to operating the Amu Zang irrigation system will be reduced through the introduction of 
water  delivery  fees  and  the  promotion  of  private  sector-driven,  non-subsidized  agriculture 
machinery services and WUAs. These measures will be preceded12 by reduction in implicit 
taxation of farms in the Amu Zang area by relaxing the Government’s mandatory procurement of 
cotton and wheat to a maximum 25% of historic average compared with the current 50%.

The Government in coordination with international organizations has facilitated in-depth poverty analysis,

In the past decade, the Government introduced reforms that would increase growth in the agriculture 
sector and reduce rural poverty. The land policy that allocated additional plots (dekhan) to families for 
private use and restructured collective and state farms into agricultural cooperatives (shirkats) intensified 
the use of scarce land and demonstrated the efficiency of private-run farms. To promote food security, the 
Government undertook measures that increased the crop area devoted to wheat production and reduced 
the  area  for  cotton  production.  The  development  of  agriculture  remains  among  the  priorities  of  the 
Government  in  2003  as  more  reforms  are  planned  for  implementation,  including  liberalization  of 
agricultural activity through the reduction of State orders for cotton and grain, rehabilitation of irrigation 
systems, institutional development through water users associations (WUAs), and the development of 
agricultural services in processing and marketing.

The country does not have a poverty partnership agreement, but is in the process of formulating its 
national living standard strategy for improving the living standards of the people. In discussions on the

areas where most of the poor reside. Productivity-enhancing measures (such as improvement of irrigation 
systems) in existing agriculture activities, institutional measures (like development  of WUAs to ensure 
sustainable and efficient use of irrigation water), and market reforms have been identified as key areas for 
decreasing rural income poverty.

D.            Gender Development 
 
While both men and women seem to have lost jobs in equal proportion, women appear to have had a 
more difficult time than men do in finding formal employment. At the national level, the rate of women 
among the officially unemployed was 62% in 2001. In the project area only 34% of women who seek 
employment have jobs. Although women provide at least 37% of the household’s income, women are 
often employed in the low-paying jobs of the state-funded social sector, and manual and seasonal 
activities in the agriculture and informal sectors. The average wage of women in Surkhandarya is 82% the 
wages of men. Women employed in shirkats also have less access to social security benefits. It was also 
noted that 40% of those surveyed were of the opinion that women should not be involved in agriculture-
related management activities. 
 
Lower female participation rates in the workforce are partly explained by high fertility rate and partly by 
cultural factors. Women with very young children are less likely to participate in the labor force, as married 
women especially in the rural areas are expected to take care of their offspring. A study noted that an 
additional child under 5 years of age reduces the female participation rate by more than 7% (footnote 3). 
Aside from rearing the young and performing household chores, rural women are in charge of the garden 
plots and livestock as well as of fetching water for drinking. Hence, access to regular supply of water for 
irrigation and for drinking is very important in lessening rural women’s burden of performing multiple roles.  
 
The overall gender strategy of the Project has a twofold objective: (i) reduce the economic burden of 
women in the project area, and (ii) improve their capacity to participate in agriculture management. This 
will done by (i) increasing the household’s access to a regular supply of water for irrigating their household 
plots, (ii) ensuring that women participate in agriculture service centers, (iii) maximizing the participation of 
women in technical and management skills training activities and project designs, (iii) providing gender 
and development training in WUAs, and (iv) ensuring women’s membership in the WUAs.
